Courtney and Kasey Crews both work full time, but the pandemic brought career uncertainty into their lives. With three children, including a son with autism, the Crews have relied on the #ChildTaxCut to continue their son‚Äôs therapy and start savings accounts for each kid.

We call health care workers our heroes. But we've got to make sure we really treat them like that. On #NPSADay, that starts with acknowledging this mental health crisis and reflecting on how we can better support our health care workforce.

I worked on this legislation with the support of Dr. Breen's sister and brother-in-law‚Äîco-founders of the @drbreenheroes foundation‚Äîas well as Virginia frontline physicians @DrCollazo and @rivakamat, and was glad to join them at the Capitol this week to urge its passage. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E_gk6qYWEAEzTGz.jpg

On this important day, I'm calling for swift and final passage of my Dr. Lorna Breen Health Care Provider Protection Act‚Äîa bipartisan bill that works to reduce and prevent suicide, burnout, and mental and behavioral health conditions among health care professionals.

When Dr. Lorna Breen, a Charlottesville native and frontline ER physician, died by suicide in April 2020, her family took their unimaginable grief and channeled it into the cause of making sure our health care professionals can come forward and ask for mental health support.

Today is National Physician Suicide Awareness Day. Now more than ever before, it is so deeply important to acknowledge the incredible burdens placed on health care professionals and the profound trauma wrought by this ongoing pandemic.
